Article.ArticleTitle: Memory Effects in Nanolaminates of Hafnium and Iron Oxide Films Structured by Atomic Layer Deposition.

AbstractText: HfO<sub>2</sub> and Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> thin films and laminated stacks were grown by atomic layer deposition at 350 °C from hafnium tetrachloride, ferrocene, and ozone. Nonlinear, saturating, and hysteretic magnetization was recorded in the films. Magnetization was expectedly dominated by increasing the content of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. However, coercive force could also be enhanced by the choice of appropriate ratios of HfO<sub>2</sub> and Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> in nanolaminated structures. Saturation magnetization was observed in the measurement temperature range of 5-350 K, decreasing towards higher temperatures and increasing with the films' thicknesses and crystal growth. Coercive force tended to increase with a decrease in the thickness of crystallized layers. The films containing insulating HfO<sub>2</sub> layers grown alternately with magnetic Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> exhibited abilities to both switch resistively and magnetize at room temperature. Resistive switching was unipolar in all the oxides mounted between Ti and TiN electrodes.
